panels.description: The percentage of CPU utilization for the entire host. (Because Redis is single-threaded, it is recommended that you monitor EngineCPUUtilization metric for nodes with 4 or more vCPUs)
panels.title: CPU Utilization by node

panels.description: The amount of free memory available on the host. This is derived from the RAM, buffers and cache that the OS reports as freeable.
panels.title: Freeable  Memory by Node

panels.description: The number of bytes the host has read from the network.
panels.title: Network Bytes In by Node

panels.description: The number of bytes sent out on all network interfaces by the instance.
panels.title: Network Bytes Out by Node

panels.description:
Calculated by

(100 x hits) / (hits + misses)
panels.title: Hit Rate

panels.description: The number of client connections, excluding connections from read replicas. ElastiCache uses two to three of the connections to monitor the cluster in each case.
panels.title: Current Connections by Cluster

panels.description: The total number of connections that have been accepted by the server during this period.
panels.title: New Connections by Cluster

panels.description: The number of successful and unsuccessful read-only key lookups in the main dictionary.
panels.title: Cache Hits & Misses by Cluster

panels.description: The total number of read-only type commands.
panels.title: Get Commands by Cluster

panels.description: The total number of write types of commands.
panels.title: Set Commands by Cluster

panels.description: The total number of read-only type commands.
panels.title: Get Commands by Node

panels.description: The total number of write-only type commands.
panels.title: Set Commands by Node

panels.description: Provides CPU utilization of the Redis engine thread. Since Redis is single-threaded, you can use this metric to analyze the load of the Redis process itself. The EngineCPUUtilization metric provides a more precise visibility of the Redis process and can be used in conjunction with CPUUtilization metric, which exposes CPU utilization for the server instance as a whole, including other operating system and management processes. (For larger node types with 4vCPUs or more, use the EngineCPUUtilization metric to monitor and set thresholds for scaling. For smaller node types with 2vCPUs or less, use the CPUUtilization metric.)
panels.title: Engine CPU Utilization by Cluster

panels.description: The amount of free memory available on the cluster. This is derived from the RAM, buffers and cache that the OS reports as freeable.
panels.title: Freeable  Memory by Cluster

panels.description: The total number of bytes allocated by Redis for all purposes, including the dataset, buffers, etc.
panels.title: Bytes Used for Cache by Cluster

panels.description: The amount of swap used on the cluster.
panels.title: Swap Usage by Cluster

panels.description: The amount of swap used on the host.
panels.title: Swap Usage by Node

panels.description: The total number of bytes allocated by Redis for all purposes, including the dataset, buffers, etc.
panels.title: Bytes Used for Cache by Node

panels.description: The total number of commands that are hash-based.
panels.title: Hash Based Commands by Cluster

panels.description: The total number of HyperLogLog-based commands.
panels.title: HyperLogLog-based commands by Cluster

panels.description: The total number of commands that are key-based.
panels.title: Key based commands by Cluster

panels.description: The total number of commands that are list-based.
panels.title: List based commands by Cluster

panels.description: The total number of commands that are set-based. This is derived from the Redis commandstats statistic by summing all of the commands that act upon one or more sets (scard, sdiff, sadd, sunion, etc).
panels.title: Set based commands by Cluster

panels.description: The total number of write types of commands. This is derived from the Redis commandstats statistic by summing all of the mutative types of commands that operate on data (set, hset, sadd, lpop, etc.)
panels.title: Set type commands by Cluster

panels.description: The total number of commands that are sorted set-based.
panels.title: Sorted set based commands by Cluster

panels.description: The total number of commands that are string-based.
panels.title: String based commands by Cluster

panels.description: The total number of commands that are stream-based
panels.title: Stream based commands by Cluster

panels.description: The number of items in the cache.
panels.title: Current Items by Cluster

panels.description: The number of value reallocations per minute performed by the active defragmentation process.
panels.title: Active Defrag Hits by Cluster

panels.description: The number of keys that have been evicted due to the maxmemory limit.
panels.title: Evictions by Cluster

panels.description: The total number of key expiration events.
panels.title: Reclaimed by Cluster

panels.description: his binary metric returns 1 whenever a background save (forked or forkless) is in progress, and 0 otherwise. A background save process is typically used during snapshots and syncs. These operations can cause degraded performance. Using the Save In Progress metric, you can diagnose whether or not degraded performance was caused by a background save process.
panels.title: Save In Progress by Cluster

panels.description: This metric is only applicable for a node running as a read replica. It represents how far behind, in seconds, the replica is in applying changes from the primary node.
panels.title: Replication Lag by Cluster

panels.description: For nodes in a replicated configuration, Replication Bytes reports the number of bytes that the primary is sending to all of its replicas. This metric is representative of the write load on the replication group.
panels.title: Replication Bytes by Cluster
